clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of Erector Spinae Block on Diaphragma Movement
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Erector Spinae Plane Block on Diaphragma Movement in Laparoscopic Cholecystectomies

brief_summary.textblock: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgeries cause moderate/severe pain and thus can result in shallow breathing, atelectasis and increased opioid consumption in the early postoperative period which in turn cause a longer hospital stay. Erector spinae plane block has been shown to decrease lower thoracic pain after laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgeries. This study aims to investigate the effect of erector spinae plane block on opioid consumption and diaphragma movement after laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgeries.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Preoperative measurement-before the erector spina plane block application and postoperative measurement- 30 minutes after extubation
primary_outcome.description: The change of diaphragma excursion as measured by ultrasound in M-mode from the preoperative period to the postoperative period

primary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 12 hours: in the first 30 minutes after extubation, 1st hour, 6th hour and 12th hour
primary_outcome.description: To assess Tramadol consumption measured in mg postoperatively in the first 12 hours after the operation

primary_outcome.time_frame: Postoperative 12 hours: in the first 30 minutes after extubation, 1st hour, 6th hour and 12th hour
primary_outcome.description: Postoperative pain will be measured with visual analog scale and numeric scale in the first 12 hours after the operation

intervention.description: Bilateral erector spinae plane block will be performed preoperatively under ultrasound guidance using 15 ml bupivacaine on each side

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ages between 18 and 65
- Patients in American Society of Anesthesiologists Classification I or II
- Elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery performed under general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient refusal
- Patients who can not provide informed consent or with a known psychiatric disease
- Patients with a known allergy to study drugs
- Patients using anticoagulants and corticosteroids
- Patients with diaphragma hernia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, lung cancer
- Patients who are not able to use a patient controlled analgesia device
